Security reminderThis studio is for education and experimentation. Do not upload production data or secrets. Outputs are demos; review before using anywhere safety-critical or financial.

Requirements and domain modelling

This lab teaches you how to frame the problem before you touch architecture. If the requirements are fuzzy, the design will be fancy but wrong.

1. Problem statement

Keep it short, but concrete. Include who benefits, what success looks like, and one constraint that matters.

2. Actors and use cases

Actors

CustomerSupport agentAdminPayment providerEmail service

Use cases

  • Customer: Browse books and see details
  • Customer: Place an order and get a confirmation

3. Functional vs non-functional

Functional requirements are what the system does. Non-functional requirements are how it behaves under stress, attack, and change.

Functional

  • Users can browse a catalogue of books.
  • Users can place an order and receive a confirmation.

Non-functional

  • Availability: the catalogue remains usable during partial outages.
  • Security: only authorised users can view order history.
  • Performance: key pages load quickly on mobile networks.

4. Domain concepts

This is not a database schema. It is a shared language. If engineers and stakeholders cannot name things the same way, delivery slows down.

Book

A sellable item with title, author, price, stock

Order

A record of purchase intent, status, and totals

Customer

A user identity and contact details

Common mistakes

  • Listing features without defining success or constraints.
  • Skipping non-functional requirements until production forces the issue.
  • Using technical jargon as a substitute for clarity.
  • Making the domain model match the database because it feels tidy.

Readiness hints

  • Looks reasonable. The next step is turning this into boundaries and interfaces.
